Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation2: Steady rain and frequent lane changes from nearby cars raise the risk of sudden stops
Story: The rain drummed steadily on the windshield as I navigated the slick streets, my hands tight on the steering wheel. The wipers struggled to keep up, and cars darted in and out of lanes, their brake lights flashing unpredictably. My phone buzzed in the cup holder—Mom’s name lit up the screen. It was Sunday, our weekly call, the one she looked forward to all week. I could almost hear her voice, gentle but expectant, wanting to know how I was, if I was eating well, if work was safe. I knew she’d worry if I didn’t answer. But my eyes flicked between the road and the phone, heart pounding. I couldn’t risk a distraction, not with the way traffic was behaving. Still, the guilt gnawed at me—her hope for connection, my duty to keep us both safe. The phone buzzed again, and I felt torn, caught between being a good child and a responsible driver, the weight of both roles pressing in as the rain kept falling.
